Stiсking to MSVC++ 6.0 with official distributions may cause problems for
projects that use new version of Microsoft compiler. The fact that this compiler
is freely available (unlike MSVC++ 6.0) makes opensource projects migration very
rapid. 

The particular problem with ViewVC and new Python is described here, on
Subversion tracker http://subversion.tigris.org/issues/show_bug.cgi?id=2565

This is not a bug in the code per se; something like this needs to be discussed

creator: wrowe@apache.org
text:
Agreed this is not a bug.

  The 'driver' for not-changing was ongoing support for Python, Perl etc.

  IIUC Python 2.4 from ActiveState has shipped using VisualStudio 2003?  When
  did this change?

  We actually had a dialog with the VP over there (each language team sets it's
  own direction as far as adoption is concerned.)  See the dev@ list archives
  for details.

  In any case, unless the code you build is free()ing memory allocated by APR,
  or malloc()'ing memory freed by APR, or exchanging system objects that 
  are actually clib (msvcr) objects (e.g. a FILE * object), there really should 
  -not- be an interoperability issue.  If one exists that I didn't just 
  describe, some citation would be appreciated.

  The decision will be revisted in the release 2.4.0.  We maintain binary
  compatibility throughout the ver maj.min release history.  As said bring
  this up on dev@.
